Law Details: Punishment: Death or life imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects you when someone is intentionally killed. Strict punishment ensures justice for victims.
Applicability: If someone intentionally causes the death of another person, or you witness such an act.
Whom to Approach: Report immediately to the nearest police station and help file an FIR.
Historical Context: Central provision in BNS replacing IPC Section 302.
Real-life Example: Intentional stabbing leads to victim's death.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects you if someone tries to kill but fails. Aims to deter violent attempts.
Applicability: If someone attacks you or another person with intent to kill, but the victim survives.
Whom to Approach: Go to the nearest police station and file a complaint/FIR. Seek medical help if injured.
Historical Context: Addresses dangerous attempts, not just completed crimes.
Real-life Example: Shooting at someone but missing.

Law Name/Section: Section 105 - Culpable Homicide Not Amounting to Murder
Law Details: Punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.
Law Summary: Used when someone's reckless act causes death without clear intent to kill.
Applicability: If a person dies due to someone else's reckless but not deliberate action.
Whom to Approach: Report to police for investigation. File an FIR.
Real-life Example: Drunk driver causes fatal accident.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects you from serious physical injuries caused intentionally.
Applicability: If you suffer a serious injury (broken bones, permanent damage, etc.) due to someone.
Whom to Approach: Report to police and seek medical help. File an FIR and provide medical records.
Real-life Example: Arm broken in an assault.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you from being intentionally hurt by someone.
Applicability: If someone slaps, hits, or physically injures you.
Whom to Approach: Go to police station and file a complaint.
Real-life Example: Slapped during an argument.

Law Name/Section: Section 117 - Voluntarily Causing Hurt by Dangerous Weapons
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment or fine or both.
Law Summary: Ensures strict punishment for attacks with weapons.
Applicability: If hurt with a knife, rod, acid, etc.
Whom to Approach: Report to police and provide evidence or witness details.
Real-life Example: Attacked with a knife.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Strict punishment for causing serious physical injuries intentionally.
Applicability: If you or someone else suffers a serious injury (fractures, loss of senses, etc.).
Whom to Approach: File a complaint at the local police station and provide medical records.
Historical Context: Covers serious injuries beyond minor hurt.
Real-life Example: Eye permanently damaged in a fight.

Law Name/Section: Section 119 - Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt by Dangerous Weapons
Law Details: Punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.
Law Summary: Protects against serious attacks using dangerous weapons.
Applicability: If injured by acid, firearms, or sharp weapons.
Whom to Approach: Report to police and seek medical treatment. Provide all details and evidence.
Historical Context: Focuses on acid attacks and weapon injuries.
Real-life Example: Acid thrown at a person during a dispute.

Law Name/Section: Section 140 - Assault or Criminal Force to Woman with Intent to Outrage Her Modesty
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects women from sexual harassment and assault.
Applicability: If you or someone else is a victim of molestation or inappropriate touch.
Whom to Approach: Go to nearest police station or women's cell to file an FIR.
Real-life Example: Woman groped in public.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Covers all forms of sexual harassment at workplace or public spaces.
Applicability: If someone makes unwelcome advances, comments, or physical contact.
Whom to Approach: Report to police or Internal Complaints Committee (for workplaces).
Real-life Example: Unwanted sexual jokes at work.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects you from being repeatedly followed or contacted against your will.
Applicability: If someone follows, sends repeated messages, or persistently watches you.
Whom to Approach: Save evidence and complain to police or cyber cell (for online stalking).
Historical Context: Added to address rising stalking incidents.
Real-life Example: Repeated messages from a stranger on social media.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects children and adults from being taken away without consent.
Applicability: If someone is abducted or missing suspiciously.
Whom to Approach: File an FIR at the nearest police station immediately.
Real-life Example: Child taken from school without parental consent.

Law Name/Section: Section 151 - Kidnapping or Abducting Woman to Compel Marriage
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects women from being forced into marriage or trafficking.
Applicability: If a woman is kidnapped or forced to marry against her will.
Whom to Approach: File a complaint at the police station or women's cell.
Real-life Example: Abducted and forced to marry abductor.

Law Details: Punishment: Not less than 10 years, may extend to life imprisonment.
Law Summary: Protects women from sexual assault; defines rape in detail.
Applicability: If any woman is forced into sexual intercourse without consent.
Whom to Approach: File an FIR at the nearest police station as soon as possible.
Historical Context: Based on ongoing gender justice reforms.
Real-life Example: Woman raped by her employer.

Law Details: Punishment: Not less than 10 years, may extend to life imprisonment.
Law Summary: Ensures severe punishment for rape offenders.
Applicability: If you or someone you know is a victim of rape.
Whom to Approach: Report to police immediately, seek medical help and counseling.
Real-life Example: Minor sexually assaulted by neighbor.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects your belongings from being stolen.
Applicability: If your money, phone, jewelry, or other items are stolen.
Whom to Approach: Report theft to the nearest police station with details and evidence.
Real-life Example: Mobile phone stolen on bus.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment or fine or both.
Law Summary: Ensures strict punishment for anyone who steals.
Applicability: If you know who stole your property or have evidence.
Whom to Approach: File an FIR at the police station and provide any witness details.
Real-life Example: Thief caught stealing bicycle.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Extra punishment for thefts in homes.
Applicability: If your house is burgled or valuables stolen.
Whom to Approach: Report immediately to the police and secure the crime scene.
Real-life Example: Burglary at night in an apartment.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Protects you from theft with violence or threat.
Applicability: If someone snatches your bag using force or threatens you with a weapon.
Whom to Approach: Report to police immediately and provide witness details if possible.
Historical Context: Defines robbery as theft plus violence.
Real-life Example: Mugged at knifepoint.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.
Law Summary: Ensures strict punishment for robbery offenders.
Applicability: If you have identified the robber or have CCTV evidence.
Whom to Approach: Give all evidence to the police during FIR/complaint.
Real-life Example: Armed robbery at a jewelry shop.

Law Details: Punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.
Law Summary: Protects against armed gang robberies (5 or more people).
Applicability: If a gang of people robs a place together.
Whom to Approach: File FIR at the police station and give all information to help catch the gang.
Real-life Example: Armed group loots a bank.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you if someone entrusted with your property cheats you.
Applicability: If your employee, banker, or agent misuses your property/money.
Whom to Approach: File a police complaint and provide all documents.
Real-life Example: Cashier runs away with company funds.

Law Name/Section: Section 181 - Criminal Breach of Trust by Public Servant/Banker
Law Details: Punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.
Law Summary: Strict punishment for public servants/bankers who cheat those who trust them.
Applicability: If a government officer or bank employee cheats you of your money/property.
Whom to Approach: File a police complaint and inform the senior officer of the department/bank.
Historical Context: Higher penalty for public trust breach.
Real-life Example: Bank officer misappropriates customer deposits.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 1 year or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you from being deceived or cheated for money/property.
Applicability: If someone tricks you into losing money, goods, or property.
Whom to Approach: Collect evidence (messages, receipts) and report to police.
Historical Context: For all types of cheating cases.
Real-life Example: Online shopping scam with fake product.

Law Name/Section: Section 191 - Cheating and Dishonestly Inducing Delivery of Property
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 7 years and fine.
Law Summary: Severe punishment for major cheating and fraud.
Applicability: If you are scammed out of significant money/property.
Whom to Approach: File a detailed police complaint with evidence (bank records, messages).
Historical Context: Famous for use in fraud cases.
Real-life Example: Investment fraud by a fake company.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 months or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects your property from unauthorized entry.
Applicability: If someone enters your house, office, or land without permission.
Whom to Approach: File a complaint with the local police station.
Real-life Example: Neighbor enters your land without consent.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 months or fine or both.
Law Summary: Punishes those who illegally enter your property.
Applicability: If you find someone trespassing.
Whom to Approach: Call police and do not confront the trespasser alone.
Real-life Example: Stranger enters backyard without permission.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you from fake documents or signatures being made in your name.
Applicability: If your signature is forged or a fake document is made about you.
Whom to Approach: Collect documents and report to police for investigation.
Real-life Example: Forged will produced after relative’s death.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Ensures punishment for creating or using forged documents.
Applicability: If you find out about a forgery.
Whom to Approach: Provide evidence to police during complaint.
Real-life Example: Fake mark sheet used for job application.

Law Name/Section: Section 220 - Using as Genuine a Forged Document
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 7 years and fine.
Law Summary: Punishes use of forged documents as if real.
Applicability: If someone submits fake documents to you, your office, or bank.
Whom to Approach: Give the suspicious document to police and ask for verification.
Historical Context: Used in employment and banking frauds.
Real-life Example: Fake ID to open bank account.

Law Name/Section: Section 240 - Counterfeiting Currency Notes or Bank Notes
Law Details: Punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.
Law Summary: Protects economy and individuals from fake currency.
Applicability: If you come across fake notes or someone tries to pay you with them.
Whom to Approach: Report immediately to police and hand over fake notes.
Historical Context: Key to fighting fake currency rackets.
Real-life Example: Fake ₹500 notes given in a shop.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects your reputation from false statements or rumors.
Applicability: If someone spreads lies about you in public, print, or online.
Whom to Approach: Collect evidence (texts, posts, publications) and file a police complaint.
Historical Context: Covers both spoken and written defamation.
Real-life Example: False rumors about a businessman in newspaper.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Ensures punishment for those who damage others’ reputation.
Applicability: If you have evidence of public defamation.
Whom to Approach: Approach police or initiate a criminal complaint in court.
Real-life Example: Defamatory post on social media.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you from threats to your life, property, or loved ones.
Applicability: If someone threatens to harm you or your family.
Whom to Approach: Report threat to police with any call/message evidence.
Historical Context: Covers all forms of threats and blackmail.
Real-life Example: Neighbor threatens to burn house.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Punishes those who threaten you with harm or violence.
Applicability: If you are threatened or blackmailed.
Whom to Approach: File a complaint with police and preserve evidence.
Real-life Example: Threatening WhatsApp messages from unknown number.

Law Details: Gesture or Act Intended to Insult the Modesty of a Woman
Law Summary: Punishment: Up to 3 years and fine.
Applicability: Protects women from verbal abuse, gestures, and acts harming dignity.
Whom to Approach: If you or another woman faces lewd remarks or actions.
Historical Context: File a complaint at police station or women's cell.
Real-life Example: Empowers women to report abuse.
column9: Catcalling or obscene gestures on the street.

Law Details: Punishes attempts to commit any crime even if not completed.
Law Summary: Protects you by penalizing incomplete criminal acts.
Applicability: If someone tries but fails to steal, hurt, or defraud.
Whom to Approach: Report the attempt to police. Provide all possible evidence.
Historical Context: Covers all attempts to commit a crime.
Real-life Example: Caught trying to break into a house but runs away.

Law Details: Punishes planning or agreeing to commit a crime.
Law Summary: Protects you from groups plotting illegal acts.
Applicability: If you know about a group planning a crime.
Whom to Approach: Inform police with any details you have.
Historical Context: Covers conspiracy even without crime completed.
Real-life Example: Gang plans to rob a bank.

Law Name/Section: Section 290 - Acts Done by Several Persons in Furtherance of Common Intention
Law Details: Punishes all members if a crime is committed together.
Law Summary: Makes all group members equally responsible.
Applicability: If you witness a group committing a crime together.
Whom to Approach: Report all participants to police, not just the main offender.
Real-life Example: Three people assault someone together.

Law Details: Defines and punishes groups gathered for illegal purposes.
Law Summary: Prevents mobs and riots.
Applicability: If a group gathers with intent to commit a crime or disturb peace.
Whom to Approach: Call police if you see suspicious gatherings.
Real-life Example: Mob gathers to block a highway.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Punishes violent mobs and disorderly assemblies.
Applicability: If you are affected by or witness a riot.
Whom to Approach: Call police and stay safe; do not confront rioters.
Real-life Example: Stone-pelting during a protest.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects society from hate speech and actions promoting communal disharmony.
Applicability: If someone incites hatred between religious or social groups.
Whom to Approach: Report such acts or speech to police with evidence (videos, posts, etc.).
Real-life Example: Public speech incites violence against a community.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 6 months or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you from acts that harm public comfort, safety, or health.
Applicability: If someone blocks roads, pollutes, or creates loud noise disturbing many people.
Whom to Approach: File a complaint with police or local authorities.
Historical Context: Covers all acts disturbing public peace.
Real-life Example: Loudspeakers used at night in residential area.

Law Name/Section: Section 351 - Negligent Act Likely to Spread Infection of Disease
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 6 months or fine or both.
Law Summary: Prevents people from spreading infectious diseases by being careless.
Applicability: If someone violates quarantine or COVID norms and puts others at risk.
Whom to Approach: Report to local police and health authorities.
Real-life Example: Person with COVID-19 attends large gathering.

Law Name/Section: Section 360 - Rash Driving or Riding on a Public Way
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 6 months or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you from accidents caused by rash or negligent driving.
Applicability: If you witness or are victim of dangerous driving.
Whom to Approach: Report vehicle details to police for action.
Historical Context: Covers all public roads and highways.
Real-life Example: Speeding cars causing frequent accidents.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 2 years or fine or both.
Law Summary: Punishes deaths caused by carelessness, such as traffic accidents.
Applicability: If someone dies due to another person’s negligent act.
Whom to Approach: Report the incident to police, especially in road accident cases.
Real-life Example: Construction firm’s negligence causes worker’s death.

Law Name/Section: Section 406 - Attempt to Cause Death by Negligence
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 1 year or fine or both.
Law Summary: Protects you if someone’s careless action nearly causes death.
Applicability: If you barely escape a fatal accident due to someone else’s negligence.
Whom to Approach: Report to police with all details and witnesses.
Real-life Example: Driver jumps red light causing near-miss.

Law Details: Punishment: Not less than 10 years, may extend to life and fine.
Law Summary: Strict punishment for causing permanent injury by acid attack.
Applicability: If you or someone else is a victim of acid attack.
Whom to Approach: Immediate medical help and report to police with all evidence.
Historical Context: Introduced after rise in acid attack cases.
Real-life Example: Woman attacked with acid after rejecting proposal.

Law Name/Section: Section 498 - Cruelty by Husband or Relatives
Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years and fine.
Law Summary: Protects married women from cruelty, harassment, or dowry demands.
Applicability: If you or someone you know faces domestic violence or dowry harassment.
Whom to Approach: Approach police or women's cell and file an FIR.
Real-life Example: Wife harassed for dowry by in-laws.

Law Details: Punishment: Up to 3 years and fine.
Law Summary: Protects all genders from sexual harassment at work.
Applicability: If you face unwelcome advances or harassment at workplace.
Whom to Approach: Report to Internal Complaints Committee and, if needed, to police.
Real-life Example: Boss makes repeated sexual comments.

Law Details: Punishes attempts to rape even if not completed.
Law Summary: Protects you from attempted sexual assault.
Applicability: If someone tries but fails to commit rape.
Whom to Approach: Report to police and seek medical help.
Historical Context: Covers all attempts at sexual violence.
Real-life Example: Assailant is caught trying to rape but victim escapes.
